ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Crestline Sanitation District is personally committed to offer superior service and to maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  The Sanitation Services Representative administers the district's safety and environmental policies. He is also responsible for various inspections of the district's two locations to ensure compliance, and oversees the entire safety and environmental programs.  These programs include hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturers documentation, Emergency Response, as well as the Risk Management Plan.

Crestline Sanitation District has coordinated emergency response efforts with the local fire department and with the Crestline Sanitation District Emergency Response Team.  In the case of a chlorine-related emergency, Crestline Sanitation District has chosen to maintain a team that will handle releases of chlorine.   The Emergency Response Team is trained to respond in a timely manner to chlorine releases.  Their mitigation efforts will stop a chlorine release prior to exceeding a maximum of 10 pounds of chlorine.  In the event of a chlorine leak, operators are trained to retreat and to call the Crestline Sanitation District Emergency Response Team.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Crestline Sanitation District was formed on January 21, 1946 to provide sewer service to the Lake Gregory area of California.  The District?s collection system has three lift stations.  These stations pump raw sewage up to higher elevations and allow flow by gravity to the Seeley Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant.

The chlorine systems owned and operated by the Crestline Sanitation District utilize chlorine to disinfect cleaned/treated water prior to discharging (this is also known as final disinfection of the effluent).

One to

n containers and 150 pound cylinders containing liquid chlorine are delivered to the facility via truck.  Before the containers and/or cylinders are accepted, plant operators inspect the containers/cylinders and valves for any signs of leakage or improper alignment of the valves.  Once accepted, the one ton containers are off-loaded utilizing the hoist, placed in special cradles, chained to the floor, dated, and the cylinder identification numbers are recorded on the chlorine inventory forms maintained in the storage room.  

One ton containers and 150-pound cylinders are connected to the plant chlorine system.  The one ton container is the primary supply while the 150-pound cylinder is placed in ?standby? service.  The primary supply of chlorine is via the one ton container.  The 150-pound cylinder will only supply chlorine to the system when the one ton container is exhausted and during change out of the one-ton.

Chlorine gas travels (under vacuum) from the container, through the container-mounted regulator, and into an automatic switchover module.  From there the chlorine gas travels (under vacuum) to the gas feed unit, where fixed and paced rotometer units measure out the proper amount of chlorine.  The fixed rotometer is set manually while the paced rotometer is tied to the plant effluent flow meter and increases or decreases with water flow.

Chlorine gas then exits the rotometers and enters a hard piped injector.  The injector mixes chlorine gas into the water stream.  As a result, the water contains elevated levels of diluted chlorine.  The chlorine solution is then transferred via piping to the three end-use points where it is mixed with the primary water treatment system.  

The maximum intended inventory of chlorine is 2 one-ton containers and 2 150-pound cylinders).

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The five year accident history (May 1999 ? May 2004) revealed that there have been no releases of chlorine that exceeded the applicable Federal Reportable Quanti

ty (10 pounds) or the California threshold of ?any? release at Crestline Sanitation District. In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from a chlorine release.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Crestline Sanitation District vigilantly maintains tight control of its chlorine systems through various process controls and monitoring.  In the event that the primary engineering or administration controls at the stations fail and result in a release of chlorine, there are multiple mechanisms at each station to minimize the impact: 1) chlorine leak detector, 2) audible/visual leak indicator sirens/lights located outside each plant, and 3) remote alarm monitoring.  If a leak detector senses a chlorine release at 3 ppm inside the chlorine room, a blue visual light is activated, and an alarm signal is simultaneously transmitted to the Plant?s controls room and the district office. The alarm signal activates an auto dialer system that calls a pre-determined list of District personnel advising them of an alarm after normal working hours.  Upon arrival at the plant the responding operator sees the blue light indicating a chlorine leak, the Crestline Sanitation District Emergency Response Team is notified.  Chlorine alarms occurring after hours and on weekends are transmitted directly to the on call operator.  If the leak occurs during a maintenance activity, operators evacuate the chlorine building and notify the Crestline Sanitation District Emergency Response Team.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Crestline Sanitation District has taken a pro-active approach to emergency response and safety at the Wastewater Treatment Plants.  The annual emergency response drills are documented and mitigation measures to improve the Team?s response are continuously being reviewed. Crestline Sanitation District has implemented all recommendations from the initial technical studies.

The Process Safety Management team is planning to complete several items over the next year as their c

ontinued effort to provide a safe work environment for the District employees.  These changes include the following items:

1.    Continue to train all employees in Process Safety Management and the facility Safety Plan/Programs.

2.    Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.

3.    Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.

4.    Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
